practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because your muscle memory requires a sterile environment where accuracy is prioritized over raw speed to prevent the cementation of bad habits that will limit your ceiling later. By focusing on correct finger placement and keeping your eyes off the keys, you are building the neural pathways required for subconscious execution, which ensures that your speed gains in later cycles are not hindered by frequent corrections or hunt-and-peck regressions during high-pressure typing tasks.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: No-look home row and vertical reach drills

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Slower-paced typing of high-frequency short words
difficulty_profile.challenging: Top-row and bottom-row reaches without visual confirmation

subjective: Decreased urge to look at hands
Confident finger placement on the 'F' and 'J' nubs

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because your brain needs to transition from processing individual letters to recognizing and executing whole word shapes to break past the initial speed plateaus. You will be training your hands to move in fluid bursts rather than discrete staccato steps, which balances your output and reduces the cognitive load of typing each character, ultimately allowing your fingers to keep pace with your thoughts without causing the mental fatigue that usually accompanies conscious letter-by-letter processing during long sessions.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Typing common English sentences in rhythm
difficulty_profile.challenging: Pushing WPM ceilings on unfamiliar vocabulary

subjective: Feeling a flow state during medium-length paragraphs
Automatic correction of typos without looking

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This phase is necessary because your transition to expert status requires the ability to handle non-standard text and technical punctuation with the same fluidity as common prose. By introducing high-complexity drills involving symbols, numbers, and technical vocabulary, you are hardening your skills against environmental changes and ensuring that your peak performance becomes your baseline. This focus prevents accuracy decay during high-stakes work, allowing your hands to operate autonomously while your conscious mind focuses entirely on the creative or analytical content of your writing.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: High-speed typing of standard literary prose
difficulty_profile.challenging: Mixing alphanumeric strings and symbols at speed

subjective: Complete disconnect between cognitive effort and typing physical action
Ability to type complex thoughts in real-time

objective: Burst speed on top 1000 English words
subjective: Recovery speed after a typing error

architect_notes: Total time commitment of 13 hours allows for two 45-minute sessions daily plus a longer weekend review.
The jump from level 1 to level 4 is significant and requires strict adherence to the 'no-look' rule from week one.
Incorporate ergonomic breaks every 25 minutes to mitigate the high dropout risk associated with repetitive strain.

practice_logs.activity: I started trying small small words without looking at the home keys but i was a bit slow
I tried keeping my eyes off the keyboard, but it's not that easy
Tried getting to top and bottom row reaches...Mehhnnn, it wasn't easy ooo

friction_signals: Difficulty and fatigue ratings (7) exceed the defined 1–5 scale parameters
Verbal feedback ('Mehhnnn, it wasn't easy ooo') indicates significant cognitive or physical strain
Sharp escalation in fatigue across three consecutive sessions on the same date
positive_signals: Strict adherence to intended strategy (vertical reaches without visual confirmation)
Increase in session duration (40 minutes) despite rising difficulty

analysis_notes: The user self-reported difficulty and fatigue levels of 7, which is an outlier relative to the 1–5 scale, signaling extreme perceived exertion.
Practice activity (top and bottom row reaches) is aligned with the 'challenging' profile of the current strategy cycle.
The progression from home row (Diff 3) to vertical reaches (Diff 7) within a single day has resulted in rapid fatigue accumulation.
No evidence of accuracy or speed metrics provided; assessment relies on self-reported exertion and activity description.
